head.title: Are We Happy? Let Us Count the Ways

hedline.hl1: Are We Happy? Let Us Count the Ways

abstract.p: Letter from Robert E Lane on May 20 article on 'happiness index' notes that per capita GNP is closely related to happiness in developing countries, but not in developed countries; drawing

block.p: Re ''A Happiness Index With a Long Reach'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20): In post-industrial societies, where happiness and affluence parted company, measures like Marc Miringoff's social health index and William J. Bennett's morality-based cultural index provide much-needed supplementary standards to per capita gross national product.

Benjamin Friedman, a political economist, criticizes Mr. Miringoff's index as a mishmash of different kinds of social ills. But he is thinking about policy implications, which are very different for infant mortality and teenage suicide, while Mr. Miringoff is drawing attention to social ills not captured by G.N.P. statistics.

Re ''A Happiness Index With a Long Reach'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20): In post-industrial societies, where happiness and affluence parted company, measures like Marc Miringoff's social health index and William J. Bennett's morality-based cultural index provide much-needed supplementary standards to per capita gross national product.

Benjamin Friedman, a political economist, criticizes Mr. Miringoff's index as a mishmash of different kinds of social ills. But he is thinking about policy implications, which are very different for infant mortality and teenage suicide, while Mr. Miringoff is drawing attention to social ills not captured by G.N.P. statistics.

Measures like Mr. Miringoff's do not pretend to be about moods or life satisfaction. That is the province of another set of indicators showing that while per capita G.N.P. is closely related to happiness in developing countries, that is not the case in developed countries.
ROBERT E. LANE New Haven, May 23, 2000
The writer is a professor emeritus of political science at Yale University.
